comments.text:
My partner and I host Sunday brunch for the neighbors in July and have used 
variations of this recipe in the past, my favorite is using Mango puree 
with Vanilla Wafers and a garnish of the fruit. It also works with Banana 
puree [or pudding] and Graham Crackers with a drizzle of chocolate sauce 
and as you said make the whipped cream yourself, store bought is crap! 

A suggestion if I may regarding plastic ware, if you invest in the 'good 
stuff' and hand wash it when the event of over, NEVER put it in the 
dishwasher, it will last for many gatherings in the future. It's a little 
more work and a lot less stuff in a landfill.

LOVE your channel, I just found you a week or so ago, and congrats on your 
GREAT pre Christmas live show!!!

top_comment.text:
Laura love your videos! A small tip.. I've seen in a couple of your other 
videos, you were struggling with keeping the plastic/Saran wrap in the 
container while trying to use the blade to cut it off... There are actually 
tabs on both sides of the box that you can push in so the plastic wrap is 
held in place and can't fall out while you're trying to use it/ cut it! ﻿

comments.author: dignity190xoxo

comments.text:
Yes I did say that and I still stand by it! But here, since the vanilla 
pudding is just for the texture and sweetness (I want the pumpkin flavor to 
stand out here) I figured it would be a good shortcut. It gives this recipe 
great texture with practically no work. Since it's right after Christmas, I 
wanted to keep things as easy as possible since Ive been cooking for days 
straight. Thanks love!
comments.author: Laura in the Kitchen

captions.text: Hi guys! I'm Laura Vitale and today I'm going to be combining two requests in one. First

of all I hope you've all had an amazing holiday
season and we're about to kick off the new

year - and I've had a lot of people request
two different things. One, a lot of you requested

- or asked - if I could share with you a great
New Year's Eve party dessert idea that would

be really great to make ahead of time and
that would be a crowd pleaser. So we're going

to do that and I'm also combining that request
with a very popular one which was a lot of

people asked 'can you please just share with
us one more pumpkin recipe before the year

is over?' I know we are right around the time
where pumpkin is pretty much going to be out

after this week and so I figured I would combine
both of those two requests into one fabulous

little treat - that last treat of the year
so we might as well go off with a bang. And
we are making mini pumpkin pie mousse shots.

They are incredibly good, such a crowd pleaser,
beautiful to look at but literally take ten

minutes to put together and they're so fabulous
- the ingredients you'll need are very few.

You'll start off with some - this is some
instant vanilla pudding mix - you've gotta

get the regular kind, not the low fat, I prefer
the whole regular kind.

I've got some heavy cream, crushed ginger
snaps, pumpkin puree, pumpkin pie spice, and
whole milk.

That, my friend, is all you're going to need.
It is such a great, great recipe - wait till
you see!

I am cheating by using some pudding mix and
that's because it's going to give me really

great texture with not a lot of work. If I
had to, right now after the holidays, make

a mousse with egg yolks and egg whites, I
would feel a little bit under pressure especially

if we're doing it for a big party, so this
is just going to do a lot of the work for
you.
And wait till you see how easy this is.

In this bowl, I've got my vanilla pumpkin
pie - my vanilla pudding mix, to that I'm

going to add some cold milk, and all I'm going
to do is mix these together until combined.

Now, to that I'm going to add my pumpkin puree,
now this is not pumpkin pie mix, this is pure

pumpkin puree because you don't want the pumpkin
pie mix because it has a lot of sugar in it,

and then to that I'm also going to add some
pumpkin pie spice and I'm going to mix these
two together.

Okay, this looks fantastic. I'm going to set
this aside because now I want to whip up my

heavy cream. Now, really, try to use heavy
cream and whip it yourself, the consistency

is so much better than the pre-made whipped
stuff so just go through the extra step of

whipping it yourself. Now you want this to
be really nice stiff peaks, so I'm going to
give it a whirl.

Okay. Se that aside just for a second, bring
my pumpkin mixture closer to me. And this

will thicken as it sits you just have to give
it a bit.
And then you take your heavy whipped cream.
Awesome.

Get it all out of the bowl, and then all I
do is I kind of just fold it all together

- you don't have to do this in any particular
order, you just want to make sure that that

heavy cream is well mixed through, you also
don't want to deflate this, so take your time.

Okay, now what I'm going to do is I'm going
to set this aside and that, again, will firm

up as it sits. But now what I'm going to work
on is kind of my serving strategy, if you
will.

What I like to use is little shot glasses,
first of all this is a tray that I put upside

down so that you can see every layer really
nicely. These are disposable little shot glasses.

They're clear so you can see everything but
best of all, at the end of the night you can

get rid of them, you don't have to bother
washing every single one of them by hand because
that would ruin any party for me.

Then what I do is I take a little spoon. So
much in food is about you know, not only flavor,
but also texture.

So what I like to do is I like to do a little
layer of gingersnaps, and all I did is I took

these gingersnaps and put them in a little
resealable plastic bag and just bashed them

up with a rolling pin until they were about
course crumbs, some are a little finer than

others because that's what I like, I like
just a little bit of sandy texture and then
rubbles - I love that!

So what I'll do is I'll just do a little layer
of my crushed gingersnaps, and then we'll
proceed to filling these all up!

And then all you do, you could either spoon
your mousse into your little shot glasses,

which trust me, it makes a giant mess if you
try and do this nice and neat and try to make
it presentable.

Or you can do what I'm doing, which is just
- I filled a disposable piping bag with the

filling. I just have a round tip - a large
round tip. I have no special tip o it because

it doesn't really make a difference in my
opinion, and then you can fill these as high

as you want to. I'm going to refill this in
just a minute.

Now let me give you just a little bit of advice:If
you filling is a little bit too runny, pop

it in the fridge for ten minutes and it just
kind of hardens up perfectly for you to be

able to pipe it. And at this point if it's
at the right consistency, you can eat it right

away, or you can do what I do. I like to sprinkle
a little bit more of my crushed gingersnaps

over top because, again, I like that texture.
But I don't like too too much otherwise it

will kind of be overpowering because I do
have a layer at the bottom as well.

And then you can serve them right away or
you can pop them in the fridge at this point.

What I do is I just take a kitchen towel and
just kind of lay it on top because it's not

really touching anything, pop it in the fridge
until you're ready to party. I like to do

this a couple hours ahead of time I find that
it's perfect and it's such an easy job you

can get anyone to do this. You can get kids
to do this, you can get you know, your neighbor

to do this whoever you want to put to work
can do this because it really is the kind

of thing you don't have to think about. And
how impressive are they?

And it, you know especially when you're having
a get together around the holidays, it's always

good to delegate a little bit so if people
come around early, let them do this job. It's

really easy, they're not going to mess this
up, and I want to show you - by the way, these

are disposable little spoons, amazing - and
then it's just the texture is quite perfect.
Right?

But when you pop it into the fridge, it sets
even more.
To die for!

Such a perfect little nibble, got a little
bit of crunch from the gingersnaps, really

nice and lovely velvety smooth, I think, personally,
I don't think this can be beaten.

I think it's a great make ahead holiday New
Year's Eve dessert that everybody will love,

and if you're feeling fancy, top it with a
little bit of whipped cream for just a little

something extra - not that it really needs
it, but it is pretty presentation.

If you enjoyed this recipe and you want to
make it for your New Year's Eve party, go

to LauraintheKitchen.com, get the recipe,
make it for your friends and family, tag me

on facebook, twitter, instagram, wherever,
so that I can see your recreation and I hope

that you have a magnificent New Year's Eve
celebration, ringing in the new year - it's

such an exciting time and I hope to bring
you so many fantastic things this upcoming

year, and thank you so much for spending the
year with me, we cooked a lot of good things,

we've definitely had a good time and made
a lot of great friendships, I feel like I

know so many of you. Almost on a personal
level which is incredible and I just want

to thank you for just a really memorable,
unforgettable year.

And I don't think 2015 is ready for us, I
think you and I are going to go very far,

we're going to do some incredible things and
I'm just so excited!

Let me know down below what you are looking
for me to bring you this upcoming 2015, whether

it's field trips, whether it's shopping trips,
whether it's outdoor segments, I want to hear

from you. I want to hear what you want to
see here on Laura in the Kitchen this upcoming

year, because after all, I do love to cook.
But I love to please you, so let me know your

suggestions down below, I hope you have a
fantastic, fantastic, fantastic FANTASTIC

New Year's Eve and New Year's Day and please,
let's give a thumbs up for this video for

the last pumpkin recipe of the season, I think
it deserves it and I think we went out with
a BANG.

Hope you've enjoyed spending time with me
and I'll see you next time! Muah!
Bye!
Going back in!

title: Pumpkin Pie Mousse Shots Recipe - Laura Vitale - Laura in the Kitchen Episode 860
